intro: Galactodenia pumila, commonly known as the dwarf milkweed, is a small herbaceous plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Apocynaceae family and is characterized by its simple, alternate leaves and clusters of small, white to pale pink flowers. The plant produces a milky sap, which is a common feature among members of its family. Galactodenia pumila typically grows in moist, sandy soils and is often found in open woods or along stream banks. Its flowers attract various pollinators, including bees and butterflies, contributing to its ecological significance.
